title: Phishing pages used for Malware Delivery

sentences: During our routine Open-Source Intelligence (OSINT) research, Cyble Research Labs came across a Twitter post wherein researchers have mentioned a Phishing URL that is also used to deliver SMS stealer malware.
Fake Patanjali Yoga Gram Payment Page delivers SMS stealer malware
titles: Fake Patanjali Yoga Gram Payment Page delivers SMS stealer malware
Phishing pages used for Malware Delivery

sentences: During our routine Open-Source Intelligence (OSINT) research, Cyble Research Labs came across a Twitter post wherein researchers have mentioned a Phishing URL that is also used to deliver SMS stealer malware.

Cyble Research Labs believes that the user could have received a spam email containing the phishing URL that steals sensitive banking information and would serve to deliver the malware to unsuspecting users.
Our analysis found that the Threat Actors (TAs) have hosted phishing pages where they pretend to assist users with failed Patanjali Yoga Gram Registration or payment issues.
titles: Fake Patanjali Yoga Gram Payment Page delivers SMS stealer malware

sentences: The malware reads the incoming SMSs and sends their content to the number provided by the TAs server. Refer to Figure 15.
Banks and other financial entities should educate customers on safeguarding themselves from malware attacks via telephone, SMSs, or emails.

In the next stage, the malware asks for banking information such as card details or net-banking credentials as per the users selection and uploads them to the server through URL: hxxps://srqc[.]online/controller/api/common/update.php as shown in Figures 4 & 5.

As this malicious activity is based on the Patanjali Yoga Gram payment process, in this phase, it redirects to a page where it asks users to confirm the refund mode for online money transfer. Refer to Figure 3.

The malware also requests for the OTP sent by the banks to the users registered mobile number or email ID and sends it to the server, as shown in Figures 9 & 10.
During our analysis, we observed that the malware initially requests the users to allow the READ_SMS permission. After that, it hides its icon from the devices screen.

The below code snippet shows that the malware sends the incoming SMSs to the number provided by the TAs.
As shown below, we observed a defined launcher activity in the malicious apps manifest file, which loads the applications first screen.
After the user has provided card details such as card number, expiry date, and CVV, the malware also requests and uploads the PIN for these cards. Refer to Figures 6 & 7.

While analyzing the dropped APK file, we observed it has a package name that contains a string related to a major international bank. This leads us to believe that the TAs could possibly also be involved in other malicious activities related to various banks.

The TAs behind this particular malware perform malicious activities to steal sensitive information to exploit the patients and users of Patanjali products; in this case, the attackers are stealing banking information. There is also the ever-present threat of TAs using this sensitive data to commit financial fraud and further propagate the malware to other devices.
The malware requests users for 8 different permissions, out of which it abuses 5. These dangerous permissions are listed below.

After gaining access to these banking credentials, the malware drops an Android APK with the name Customer_Support from the server URL: hxxps://srqc[.]online/Customer_Support.apk, as shown in the below figure.

During our routine Open-Source Intelligence (OSINT) research, Cyble Research Labs came across a Twitter post wherein researchers have mentioned a Phishing URL that is also used to deliver SMS stealer malware.
Our analysis found that the Threat Actors (TAs) have hosted phishing pages where they pretend to assist users with failed Patanjali Yoga Gram Registration or payment issues.
Our analysis found that the Threat Actors (TAs) have hosted phishing pages where they pretend to assist users with failed Patanjali Yoga Gram Registration or payment issues.

When a user first visits the URL: hxxps://srqc[.]online/, they will see a page with the Patanjali logo and a form that requests the patients full name, failed transaction type (i.e., ATM card, net banking), and registered mobile number. Refer to Figure 1.
Figure 1 Requesting Users Information

As this malicious activity is based on the Patanjali Yoga Gram payment process, in this phase, it redirects to a page where it asks users to confirm the refund mode for online money transfer. Refer to Figure 3.
Figure 3 Refund Type

In the next stage, the malware asks for banking information such as card details or net-banking credentials as per the users selection and uploads them to the server through URL: hxxps://srqc[.]online/controller/api/common/update.php as shown in Figures 4 & 5.

In the next stage, the malware asks for banking information such as card details or net-banking credentials as per the users selection and uploads them to the server through URL: hxxps://srqc[.]online/controller/api/common/update.php as shown in Figures 4 & 5.
After the user has provided card details such as card number, expiry date, and CVV, the malware also requests and uploads the PIN for these cards. Refer to Figures 6 & 7.
After the user has provided card details such as card number, expiry date, and CVV, the malware also requests and uploads the PIN for these cards. Refer to Figures 6 & 7.

Figure 6 Requests for PIN
After the user has provided card details such as card number, expiry date, and CVV, the malware also requests and uploads the PIN for these cards. Refer to Figures 6 & 7.

After gaining access to these banking credentials, the malware drops an Android APK with the name Customer_Support from the server URL: hxxps://srqc[.]online/Customer_Support.apk, as shown in the below figure.
Figure 9 Requests for OTP
Figure 10 Sends OTP to the Server

It is one of the largest providers of Ayurvedic/Yogic treatment in the world. We have listed some essential cybersecurity best practices that create the first line of control against attackers. We recommend that our readers follow the best practices given below:
We have listed some essential cybersecurity best practices that create the first line of control against attackers. We recommend that our readers follow the best practices given below:

Download and install software only from official app stores like Google Play Store or the iOS App Store.<crlf>Use a reputed anti-virus and internet security software package on your connected devices, such as PCs, laptops, and mobile devices.<crlf>Use strong passwords and enforce multi-factor authentication wherever possible.<crlf>Enable biometric security features such as fingerprint or facial recognition for unlocking the mobile device where possible.<crlf>Be wary of opening any links received via SMS or emails delivered to your phone.<crlf>Ensure that Google Play Protect is enabled on Android devices.<crlf>Be careful while enabling any permissions.<crlf>Keep your devices, operating systems, and applications updated.
Regularly check the Mobile/Wi-Fi data usage of applications installed on mobile devices.<crlf>Keep an eye on the alerts provided by Anti-viruses and Android OS and take necessary actions accordingly.
